docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Robin Coombs, a British immunologist who in the 1940's invented a blood test that bears his name and a version of which is still widely used to diagnose some kinds of anemia and to prevent negative reactions to transfusions, died on Jan. 25, said the British Society for Immunology, a professional group he helped found. He was 85. His death was not widely reported in the British press until this month.

headline.main: Robin Coombs, 85, Inventor Of a Diagnostic Blood Test

docs.abstract: Dr Robin Coombs, British immunologist who invented diagnostic blood test that bears his name, dies at age 85 (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Robin Coombs invented a blood test that is still widely used to diagnose some kinds of anemia and to prevent negative reactions to transfusions.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''When the Stork Brings Something Extra: A Good Parking Spot,'' by Peter Applebome (Our Towns column, March 19): Anita Young of the National Organization of Women of New Jersey asks, ''Since when is being pregnant a handicap?'' I can't speak for New Jersey, but in New York City, where I was pregnant six years ago, one might also ask, ''When is being pregnant a disability?''
docs.abstract: Jill H Bennett letter responds to March 19 Our Towns column about proposal to include pregnancy as grounds for using handicapped parking spaces in New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, a pregnant Pittsburgh Steelers fan told local reporters that she had asked her doctor to induce labor early so she could watch the Super Bowl. Once her obstetrician determined that the procedure would be safe, and that the Steelers were in fact headed to the big game, he consented. (Ultimately, the woman went into spontaneous labor and gave birth naturally.)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-26-06: PHENOMENON

docs.abstract: Tina Cassidy article on trend toward inducing labor, sometimes for no other reason than that the mother wants it; in 2003, one-fifth of American births were induced, high rate given induction's increased risk of complications; induction used to be employed sparingly, to save life of mother or child; resistance to such practice may be developing because inductions require regular monitoring, thus using hospital's staff and resources; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Physicians and pregnant women are increasingly choosing to induce labor. Are they putting convenience before common sense and health?

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Rachel Gortman gets upset, she turns to her pen, not her punch. ''My notepad is my boxing bag,'' Rachel, a ninth grader at Roosevelt High School, said at a recent session of the Young Women's Writing Project at Hofstra University. ''When I get mad, I have a venting place to write my feelings down, and then I always feel much better.''

headline.main: The Power of the Adolescent Pen

docs.abstract: Article on group of 29 girls from Roosevelt Middle School and High School who attended recent session of Young Women's Writing Project at Hofstra University; program is forum for girls to express their thoughts and feelings through writing; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1877, Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell, describing what he called his ''rest cure'' for hysterical women, wrote, ''I do not permit the patient to sit up or to sew or write or read. The only action allowed is that needed to clean the teeth.'' At the end of six weeks to two months of such treatment, he expected that women would be good as new. A few years later, Charlotte Perkins Gilman was prescribed Mitchell's rest cure for postpartum depression, and her fictionalized account of its effects in ''The Yellow Wallpaper'' depicts a woman descending slowly but surely into insanity. As someone who was prescribed bed rest two years ago when I was pregnant with my daughter, I know that Gilman, not Mitchell, gets closer to the truth.
docs.snippet: Obstetricians in the United States are too quick toprescribe bed rest.

docs.lead_paragraph: THAT artists can go in and out of style is not news. The interesting question is why? Why besides the fickleness of taste would a given artist's work be so desirable at one time and not at another? Consider the 17th-century Dutch painter who is the subject of a modest but captivating exhibition called ''Amorous Intrigues and Painterly Refinement: The Art of Frans van Mieris'' at the National Gallery of Art. The 34-painting show was organized by the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis, The Hague, in association with the National Gallery of Art.

headline.main: Center Stage, With Vermeer In the Wings

docs.snippet: The captivating exhibition offers 34 of the 17th-century Dutch painter's small, amazingly concentrated portraits and paintings of everyday life.

docs.lead_paragraph: A senior cadet at the Coast Guard Academy here was accused on Tuesday of raping his former girlfriend after she passed out drunk, and of several other sexual assaults of female classmates that could lead the 130-year-old academy to hold its first court-martial proceeding involving a student. In a hearing to determine if the case should go to a court-martial, Kristin M. Strizki, a Navy midshipman who is close to the former girlfriend and said she was drinking heavily with her on the night that the rape is said to have taken place, testified on Tuesday that she encountered the accused cadet, Webster M. Smith, the next morning. She said Mr. Smith told her to take the alleged victim ''to get the morning-after pill,'' which can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of intercourse.

headline.main: Coast Guard Cadet Is Accused of Rape and Other Assaults at Academy

docs.abstract: Webster M Smith, senior cadet at Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn, is accused of raping former girlfriend, identified only as Cadet A, and of at least seven other sexual assaults of female classmates; hearing will determine if 130-year-old academy will hold its first court-martial proceeding involving student; hearing is presided over by special investigating officer Cmdr Steven Andersen (M)
docs.snippet: The charges could lead the 130-year-old Coast Guard Academy to hold its first court-martial proceeding involving a student.
